raw_text:
World leaders gather to face uncertainty
 
 More than 2,000 business and political leaders from around the globe are arriving in the Swiss mountain resort Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). For five days, they will discuss issues ranging from China's economic power to Iraq's future after this Sunday's elections. UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are among the more than 20 government leaders and heads of state leaders attending the meeting. Unlike previous years, protests against the WEF are expected to be muted. Anti-globalisation campaigners have called off a demonstration planned for the weekend.
 
 The Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the rival World Social Forum, timed to run in parallel with the WEF's ritzier event in Davos.
 
 The organisers of the Brazilian gathering, which brings together thousands of campaigners against globalisation, for fair trade, and many other causes, have promised to set an alternative agenda to that of the Swiss summit. However, many of the issues discussed in Porto Alegre are Davos talking points as well. "Global warming" features particularly high. WEF participants are being asked to offset the carbon emissions they cause by travelling to the event. Davos itself is in deep frost. The snow is piled high across the mountain village, and at night the wind chill takes temperatures down to minus 20C and less.
 
 Ultimately, the forum will be dominated by business issues - from outsourcing to corporate leadership - with bosses of more than a fifth of the world's 500 largest companies scheduled to attend.
 
 But much of the media focus will be on the political leaders coming to Davos, not least because the agenda of this year's forum seems to lack an overarching theme. "Taking responsibility for tough choices" is this year's official talking point, hinting at a welter of knotty problems. One thing seems sure, though: transatlantic disagreements over how to deal with Iran, Iraq and China are set to dominate discussions. Pointedly, only one senior official from President Bush's new administration is scheduled to attend. The US government may still make a conciliatory gesture, just as happened a year ago when Vice President Dick Cheney made a surprise appearance in Davos.
 
 Ukraine's new president, Viktor Yushchenko, is to speak, just days after his inauguration, an event that crowned the civil protests against the rigged first election that had tried to keep him from power.
 
 The European Union's top leaders, among them German Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder and European Commission President Manuel Barosso, will be here too. Mr Blair will formally open the proceedings, although his speech will be pre-empted by French President Jacques Chirac, who announced his attendance at the last minute and secured a slot for a "special message" two hours before Mr Blair speaks. The organisers also hope that the new Palestinian leader, Mahmoud Abbas, will use the opportunity for talks with at least one of the three Israeli deputy prime ministers coming to the event, a list that includes Shimon Peres. Davos fans still hark back to 1994, when talks between Yassir Arafat and Mr Peres came close to a peace deal. Mr Blair's appearance will be keenly watched too, as political observers in the UK claim it is a calculated snub against political rival Chancellor Gordon Brown, who was supposed to lead the UK government delegation.
 
 Microsoft founder Bill Gates, the world's richest man and a regular at Davos, will focus on campaigning for good causes, though business interests will not be wholly absent either. Having already donated billions of dollars to the fight against Aids and Malaria, Mr Gates will call on world leaders to support a global vaccination campaign to protect children in developing countries from easily preventable diseases. On Tuesday, Mr Gates pledged $750m (£400m) of his own money to support the cause. Mr Gates' company, software giant Microsoft, also hopes to use Davos to shore up its defences against open source software like Linux, which threaten Microsoft's near monopoly on computer desktops. Mr Gates is said to be trying to arrange a meeting with Brazil's President Lula da Silva. The Brazilian government has plans to switch all government computers from Microsoft to Linux. At Davos, global problem solving and networking are never far apart.
llama3.2:1b: Over 2,000 business and political leaders from around the world will attend the World Economic Forum in Davos for five days. UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are among attendees. The WEF's agenda includes discussion of China's economic power, Iraq's future after elections, and global warming. Business leaders, including bosses of over a fifth of the world's largest companies, will attend. However, much media focus will be on political leaders, particularly those from President Bush's administration. Ukraine's new president and Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas are scheduled to speak, while Microsoft founder Bill Gates will campaign for good causes and support global vaccination efforts.
llama3.2:3b: More than 2,000 business and political leaders gather in Davos for the World Economic Forum, discussing issues like China's economic power, Iraq's future, and global warming. The event features UK PM Tony Blair, SA President Thabo Mbeki, and US officials, but lacks an overarching theme. Transatlantic disagreements over Iran, Iraq, and China are expected to dominate discussions, with only one senior Bush official in attendance. European leaders, including Germany's Gerhard Schroeder and the EU's Manuel Barosso, will also participate. Microsoft founder Bill Gates will focus on philanthropy and business interests, and Brazil's President Lula da Silva plans to discuss switching government computers to Linux.
gemma2:2b: Over 2000 business and political leaders from around the world gathered in Davos for the World Economic Forum. Topics discussed included China's economy, Iraq's future following elections, and climate change. The event featured several high-profile attendees such as Tony Blair and Thabo Mbeki.  The WEF, however, lacked a central theme. While business issues dominated discussions, political leaders will focus on issues like Iran, Iraq, and China, with US participation expected to be low. Ukrainian president Viktor Yushchenko, the EU's top leaders, Bill Gates and Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas were also scheduled to speak. Protests against the WEF have been muted this year.
qwen2.5:0.5b: The World Economic Forum (WEF) convenes in Davos, Switzerland, for five days of discussions on issues ranging from climate change and corporate leadership to economic power and political conflicts. The forum will host two rival sides: the Brazilian city of Porto Alegre hosting the rival World Social Forum timed for parallel proceedings with WEF's Davos event, and an all-European gathering with US President George W. Bush, French President Jacques Chirac, and German Chancellor Gerhard Schmidt. Key topics include business matters such as corporate leadership and carbon offsets, with the forum dominated by economic discussions - including global warming and the fight against Iran, Iraq, and China.
qwen2.5:1.5b: More than 2,000 leaders gather in Switzerland for the annual World Economic Forum focusing on business issues amid concerns over climate change, international relations, and political leadership. Political figures like US President Bush's Vice President Dick Cheney and UK Prime Minister Tony Blair attend alongside business tycoons from around the world discussing economic power dynamics and global politics. The Swiss forum aims to promote networking among leaders while the Brazilian social forum focuses on fair trade and opposing globalization.
qwen2.5:3b: World leaders gather in Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF), where they discuss issues ranging from China’s economic power to Iraq’s future after elections. Over 20 government leaders attend alongside more than 2,000 business leaders. The WEF is held against the backdrop of a planned demonstration by anti-globalisation campaigners at the rival World Social Forum in Porto Alegre. Davos itself experiences deep frost and cold weather. Key political issues like Iran, Iraq, and China will dominate discussions with only one US administration official attending. Notable speakers include Ukraine’s new president, European Union leaders, Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas, and Microsoft founder Bill Gates focusing on global health and software competition.
opencoder:1.5b: The text summarizes the key ideas and details of the World Economic Forum (WEF) event at Davos. It covers the discussion on issues like China's economic power, global warming, carbon emissions, international politics, and globalisation campaigns. The key focus is on business interests while also highlighting international affairs with speeches from top leaders.
smollm:1.7b: The World Economic Forum (WEF) is an annual gathering of world leaders that brings together business, political, and civil society leaders to discuss global issues such as economic growth, climate change, and human rights. The WEF is a private organization, not a government agency, and its activities are funded by the governments of its member countries.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, I need to summarize the given text concisely. Let me read through it carefully first.

The main event is the World Economic Forum in Davas, hosted by a bunch of leaders. There's also a World Social Forum happening at Porto Alegre. The US Prime Minister and South African President are attending, but their discussions lack an overarching theme. They're focused on business issues with political leaders mainly, especially looking into Iran, Iraq, and China.

There are updates on European leaders too, including Bill Gates focusing on good causes like global vaccination and open-source software. Microsoft is also involved in tech discussions to defend against Linux. The US government might try to meet Brazil's President, and the Brazilian government plans to switch all computers to Linux at the conference.

So I should capture all these points but keep it concise without adding explanations or formatting.
</think>

The annual World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davas, Switzerland, attracts over 2,000 business leaders from around the globe. The WEF and a parallel World Social Forum in Porto Alegre, which host anti-globalisation campaigners, aim to discuss issues like fair trade and sustainable development. US Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are attending, but discussions lack an overarching theme, focusing instead on business issues with political leaders discussing challenges such as outsourcing, corporate leadership, and environmental concerns. The event will be dominated by business-focused topics, including global warming. Despite this, media coverage will emphasize the political agenda, especially as discussions on transatlantic issues over Iran, Iraq, and China dominate. Ukraine's new president, Viktor Yushchenko, will speak soon after his inauguration. European leaders, including Germany's Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder and Europe's President Manuel Barosso, are also attending, though US Vice President Dick Cheney previously made a surprise appearance at Davas. Microsoft founder Bill Gates is opening proceedings for good causes, like vaccinating children in developing countries, while focusing on business interests. The US government may try to meet Brazil's President Lula da Silva, with the Brazilian government planning to transition all computers to Linux at the conference.
tinyllama:1.1b: Amidst the controversy surrounding the World Economic Forum (WEF), world leaders and political leaders gathered in Davos for the annual gathering. Topics discussed include China's economic power, Iraq's future after Sunday's elections, and issues ranging from globalization to fair trade. Unlike previous years, protesters planned a counter-event at the meeting but it was called off due to protests against the WEF. Brazilian supporters of fair trade will hold a counter-event, highlighting the economic concerns and political disagreements in transatlantic relationships. The forum is being marked by political leaders such as French President Jacques Chirac, German Chancellor Gerhard Schroeeder, and European Commission President Manuel Barroso. Attendees include US Vice President Dick Cheney, but the new Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas will use the opportunity for talks with Israeli deputy prime ministers Shimon Perez and Ya'ssir Araft. The organisers also hope for an appearance from Microsoft founder Bill Gate to campaign for good causes. Other attendees include business interests, and politics are keenly watched in Davos. The World Economic Forum (WEF) is a forum that brings together the world's top business executives, policy makers, academics, and opinion leaders to discuss current challenges and opportunities.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
The World Economic Forum (WEF) has brought together around 2,000 business and political leaders from around the globe, with participants discussing issues like China's economic power, climate change, and Iraq's future after Sunday's elections. British Prime Minister Tony Blair is scheduled to deliver a speech at the meeting on Monday, addressing concerns about corruption in countries affected by conflicts. Brazilian President Thabo Mbeki will also be present, having previously planned to attend the World Social Forum in Davos but choosing to cancel due to protests.

The 2008 edition of the WEF attracted more than 35,000 participants from over 170 countries and covers a wide range of topics including corporate social responsibility, leadership development, and global governance. This year's forum features numerous speakers, including US President George W. Bush, European Union President Dick Cheney, and Russian President Vladimir Putin. Additionally, the event will host over 150 groups, representing a diverse range of stakeholders from governments, businesses, and civil society organizations.
phi:2.7b: World leaders from around the globe will gather in the Swiss mountain resort Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF) where they will discuss issues such as China's economic power, Iraq's future after elections, outsourcing, and corporate leadership. Anti-globalisation campaigners have called off a planned demonstration due to concerns over safety following the recent terrorist attacks. The Brazilian city of Porto Alegre is set to host an alternative gathering for those against globalisation, but many of the issues discussed there will also be present in Davos. "Global warming" is particularly high on the agenda for this year's forum, with WEF participants encouraged to offset their carbon emissions by travelling to the event. Ultimately, the forum will focus primarily on business-related topics and the leaders attending are expected to discuss outsourcing and corporate leadership. However, many political leaders including the US Vice President, Ukrainian President Viktor Yushchenko, and European Commission President Manuel Barosso will also be present at Davos. The European Union's top leaders will be in attendance as well, with a focus on issues such as Iran, Iraq, and China. Microsoft founder Bill Gates will attend to support efforts to vaccinate children against easily preventable diseases. The forum is seen as an opportunity for world leaders to network and solve global problems.
orca-mini:3b: World leaders gather in Switzerland for the annual World Economic Forum, where business and political leaders discuss issues ranging from China's economic power to Iraq's future after Sunday's elections. Tony Blair and Thabo Mbeki are among the more than 20 government leaders and heads of state attending the meeting. Protests against the forum are expected to be muted this year due to the lack of a clear overall theme, but business issues such as outsourcing, corporate leadership, and fair trade remain at the forefront. Global warming is also a key topic, with many WEF participants offsetting their carbon emissions by traveling to the event. Davos itself is in deep frost, with temperatures dropping below minus 20C at night. The forum will be dominated by business issues, but much of the media focus will be on political leaders coming to Davos, including Ukraine's new president and European Union officials.
hermes3:3b: World leaders meet at Davos for annual WEF discussion, including issues like China's economic power, Iraq's future after elections, transatlantic disagreements over Iran, Iraq and China, European Union top leaders attending, protests expected to be muted compared to previous years.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: More than 2,000 business and political leaders gather at the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos for discussions on various issues including China's economic power and Iraq's future. This year, protests against the WEF are expected to be muted, with anti-globalization campaigners calling off their planned demonstration. The Brazilian city of Porto Alegre hosts the rival World Social Forum parallel to the WEF event. The forum will focus on business issues and political leaders including UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki. Key topics for discussion include global warming, responsibility for tough choices, Iran, Iraq, and China. Bill Gates, the world's richest man, focuses on campaigning for good causes while also addressing business interests at Davos.

UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are among the attendees, while protests against the WEF are expected to be minimal. Meanwhile, the rival World Social Forum in Brazil will focus on anti-globalization and fair trade. stablelm2:1.6b:
World leaders gather in the Swiss resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF), discussing issues ranging from China's economic power to Iraq's future following elections. UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki attend alongside more than 2,0..

granite3.1-dense:2b:
More than 2,000 business and political leaders, including UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki, gather in Davos for the World Economic Forum (WEF) to address global issues such as China's economic influence, Iraq's future elections, and climate change. Unlike past years, protests against the WEF are minimal due to anti-globalization campaigners canceling their demonstration. In parallel, Porto Alegre hosts the World Social Forum, bringing together thousands of activists advocating for fair trade and other causes. Davos' weather contrasts with its ritzy nature, as snow piles up and temperatures drop to minus 20C at night.

The WEF focuses on business topics like outsourcing and corporate leadership, with participants from over a fifth of the world's largest companies attending. However, the forum lacks an overarching theme; this year's talking point is "taking responsibility for tough choices." Key political discussions will revolve around transatlantic disagreements on Iran, Iraq, and China. Notable absentees include a senior US official from President Bush's administration, with only Vice President Dick Cheney present last year.

Notable attendees include Ukraine's new president, Viktor Yushchenko; EU leaders like German Chancellor Gerhard Schroeder and European Commission President Manuel Barosso; and newly elected Palestinian leader Mahmoud Abbas. Microsoft founder Bill Gates, the world's richest man, will focus on global vaccination campaigns to combat preventable diseases in developing countries. Additionally, he aims to meet with Brazil's President Lula da Silva regarding potential government computer software changes from Microsoft to Linux.

At Davos, political and business leaders engage in problem-solving and networking, with expectations for meaningful discussions on global challenges.
